title: Do college application essays need titles? If so, how do I come up with a good one? - Quora

response.answer_text: College application essays do not need titles. In fact, most application essays do not have one. You may, of course, choose to add one if you feel like it adds value to the essay, but in most cases I would suggest not using one if not explicitly asked to provide a title. Other than the possibility that you might come up with a cheesy or otherwise less-than-optimal title, adding a title might create preconceived notions for your reader of what to expect, which may not be what you want. A college admissions officer who has taken an interest in your application is guaranteed to read your application essay, unlike an essay in an anthology or magazine. If well written, the introduction to the essay itself should do the job. There is no need to draw in the reader with an interesting title.  You should, however, begin your essay with an interesting "hook." This could be a challenging or surprising statement or fact, or perhaps an opening paragraph that employs in medias res.

Simple answer: No. Long answer: To be honest, as a procrastinator, I’d find any reason to avoid doing the task at hand (writing). So, eliminate this distraction. This is not necessary and in fact, it can be tacky. If you are done writing your essay and you want to add a title, it will be something that comes to you, but it can be a little corny. Thinking back at my college essay, would my title have been: “Little Macedonian girl wants to help people” or “When doctors don’t help you, you want to help others..” or something along those lines. First, I don’t want the admissions committee to get a different idea, and then be disappointed by a title that over-promises or over-simplifies my essay…when it is superfluous to begin with. Back to the short answer: No. :)

If you have a title that adds value to the essay great, but don’t spend lots of time laboring over it. It doesn’t add much to the essay itself, and it’s very likely it will be passed over rather quickly in the process. And as for the post that recommended an essay writing service — just don’t. It’s great to work with a coach to help write the essay more effectively, especially if it will help you learn to be a more effective writer. To outsource the entire process is a move loaded with missteps. Will the essay match up with your grades in English? Will it be consistent with the other parts of your application? The college application process should help you find a school where you can thrive and achieve your goals. Name recognition of the school you attend doesn’t help at all if you end up having to transfer somewhere else after the first year because it wasn’t the right fit.

I’m unclear from your question if you mean college APPLICATION essays or essays you are turning in for a college class. In general, college application essays do not have a title. Particularly true if you are responding to a specific prompt and you are given a low word count to work around. In general, essays turned in for college classes do require a title unless the professor gives specific instructions that it’s okay to omit it. If in doubt, go to your professor’s office hours to inquire or many universities have free writing labs which offer writing guidance.

I like titles. But they need to be good. A title should be short and witty. Not cutesy. The tone of the title and essay should match. The best ones don’t give away too much about the essay, and only hint at what’s to come. Do not use questions. And don’t even think about a title that sounds anything like “My College Application Essay.” Now, how do you think of a title, a good title? No. A title may be useful for some essays, and inappropriate for others. The purpose is to set the stage — to make the reader anxious to read more. Keep in mind that essays arrive by the truckload, and getting picked out of the pile of “things I have to read sooner or later” gives you a definite advantage.

They do not need titles. What you need is compelling arguments which sell your profile. Get yourself some professional help to make sure that your essays do what thy are supposed to do. Forget minutia. Forget the gossip that floats through chat groups.

Depends on the style guide you are using. The MLA Handbook, for instance, has a set place for your title on the fifth line of the first page, and it provides clear instructions on how to capitalize it. However, not all disciplines have such rules spelled out. Ask your teacher what format you are to use for your paper (i.e., what style guide) and then follow its policy for a title.

Absolutely. Would you buy a book with just a plain cover and no title? Of course not. Essays should have either a title page or the tile of the essay at ALL times. Check Purdue Owl for all of your writing help.
College essays have a “prompt.” You simply respond to the prompt. No other title is needed.
